item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
I‚Äôm bearish on software-only startups / products.

The first rule of business is that success comes from differentiation, and building software is no longer a differentiation.

The alpha has shifted to whatever you can‚Äôt vibe code - the messy / boring / unsexy parts like building an on-ground logistics network, nurturing customer or vendor relationships, investing in brand or distribution and so on.

So if you‚Äôre building a startup, ask yourself: what part of it isn‚Äôt replicable in one or few Claude code sessions?

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 25, 2026

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
Guys - it's Claude Code's actual first birthday today - Feb 24 2025 was the launch, check it

am i crazy or is @latentspacepod the only one doing a retrospective + anniversary pod today? did everyone just forget the most consequential AI product since ChatGPT?

anyway... we did one :) @fabknowledge is an old friend and self proclaimed psychosis patient. We do the postmortem + premortem the next +100% runup in the Global Memory shortage, wherein I make the prediction that LLM context lengths will -NOT- 10x with full attention in the next 2-4 years.

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
The people who build Claude Code, and everyone across Anthropic, are the reason any of this happened.

Same goes for every developer who's been building with us, breaking things, and telling us about it. You've all made this better than we could on our own.

Lots more to do.

The people who build Claude Code, and everyone across Anthropic, are the reason any of this happened.

Same goes for every developer who's been building with us, breaking things, and telling us about it. You've all made this better than we could on our own.

Lots more to do.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 25, 2026

Replying to:

Boris Cherny @bcherny

We shipped Claude Code as a research preview a year ago today.

Developers have used it to build weekend projects, ship production apps, write code at the world's largest companies, and help plan a Mars rover drive.

We built it, and you showed us what it was for. https://t.co/Pzh2vIDwnv

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
some illuminati somewhere decided today was Launch Everything Day but just sharing some personal commentary from this as an analyst:

- Scott admits Devin didn‚Äôt even have internal PMF at the 2024 launch. took 6 months to get adoption at first enterprise customer. Models werent ready. trying out a lot of agent patterns. But: the form factor was right. Async agents are the Final Boss of agent ux.

- Devin usage doubled every 2 months in 2025 per each enterprise after landing. Doubling rate has *accelerated* to every 6 weeks so far this year (!!) internal usage is now 4x 2025 peak.

- Self serve sucked because repo setup was effectively not worked on (doesnt matter to enterprises if FDEs are just gonna set them up for you lol)

- with Devin 2.2 that is now changing. Cog hired first designer 2 months ago (another lol). team did a crazy allhands 3 Sundays ago and decided to do a big sprint to catch up all the self serve UX debt that has been piling up. this means lots of polish but also integrating things with the new omnibox and seamlessly tying in devin review with devin main to ‚Äúclose the loop‚Äù.

point being, this team has been building background agents since long before it was cool and honestly well before they were working. instead of chasing trend after trend in 2025 they found pmf and battle tested for the past year in the largest enterprises in the world - by the way the single most impt customer profile in coding.

and now allow them to reintroduce themselves with a basically complete reworking of what its like to use Devin. again dont take my word for it - take my designer‚Äôs word who has been going absolutely fucking HAM because he now has his own senior engineer reading his figma and translating his vision to code. see screenshots. I‚Äôm feeling the agi myself.

and‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ look out for Devin 3.0 :)

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
I don't think so. The market for $3M+ houses in the region has always been strange. I think it has more to do with this particular house not preserving its value due to its age and style, and the appreciation of the land wasn't enough to counter that. It also seems like the current seller wants to sell quickly. The last time it sold, it was on the market for 3 years, and this time the current owner has dropped the price by $1M after just one month on the market.

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:
@CodveAi Did openclaw write this?

@CodveAi Did openclaw write this?

— Chris Albon (@chrisalbon) February 24, 2026

Replying to:

Codve.ai @CodveAi

@chrisalbon OpenClaw orchestration is great for this - you can spawn multiple sub-agents from a single coordinator and manage them through a unified interface. Each agent runs in its own context but the orchestrator handles the lifecycle. Much cleaner than tmux juggling!
item.content:encoded:

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
one of the most impressive teams in AI I‚Äôve ever been honored to meet. going to their christmas party last year was a big ‚Äúoh wow‚Ä¶. they are assembling some low key legends up and down the stack‚Äù moment for me. fun fact: when they were fundraising in 2023 NOBODY wanted to touch them because the received wisdom was that the last generation of custom chip startups were abject failures.

congrats on the B! as we run into more and more memory and compute tradeoffs with exponential demand for speed and throughput, i think innovation at this layer makes sense especially as the workload shape stabilizes. The Hardware Lottery doesnt always have to go to the same winners every year‚Ä¶

one of the most impressive teams in AI I‚Äôve ever been honored to meet. going to their christmas party last year was a big ‚Äúoh wow‚Ä¶. they are assembling some low key legends up and down the stack‚Äù moment for me. fun fact: when they were fundraising in 2023 NOBODY wanted to touch them because the received wisdom was that the last generation of custom chip startups were abject failures.

congrats on the B! as we run into more and more memory and compute tradeoffs with exponential demand for speed and throughput, i think innovation at this layer makes sense especially as the workload shape stabilizes. The Hardware Lottery doesnt always have to go to the same winners every year‚Ä¶

— swyx (@swyx) February 24, 2026

Quoting:

Reiner Pope @reinerpope

We‚Äôre building an LLM chip that delivers much higher throughput than any other chip while also achieving the lowest latency. We call it the MatX One.

The MatX One chip is based on a splittable systolic array, which has the energy and area efficiency that large systolic arrays

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
Nice. Highly recommended :)

Property taxes are slightly above average here (~1% vs 0.9%), but far from the most expensive. A big part of the east coast is 1.5-2% (NY, NJ, etc).

But we don't have state income tax, which is definitely uncommon. Then sales tax (VAT) is high at around 10%, where a lot of other states have much lower or even nothing.

Nice. Highly recommended :)

But we don't have state income tax, which is definitely uncommon. Then sales tax (VAT) is high at around 10%, where a lot of other states have much lower or even nothing.

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 24, 2026

Replying to:

Kilian Ekamp @KilianEkamp

@dvassallo Nice! You‚Äôve grown some roots in Washington :) Right now, I can rather see myself buying a house in the US at some point than for example in Spain. But then again, the property taxes are not to be underestimated. Is your county especially expensive, or is that average?

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:
Every year I have to fill out an IRS gift tax form. I don‚Äôt owe any taxes because I haven‚Äôt gifted $13,999,000 but apparently I need to tell the IRS every year.

I always hated that form, but this year I dumped everything into GPT and it did it perfectly. Better living with AI!

this doesn‚Äôt look good at all on anthropic especially with such low exchange numbers of 150k or few million.

if you ran a full bench suite with pass@8 or something anyone can get such numbers.

totally unconvincing and deliberately inciting in messaging to curb open source. https://t.co/ZVKOZ5ksaW

this doesn‚Äôt look good at all on anthropic especially with such low exchange numbers of 150k or few million.

if you ran a full bench suite with pass@8 or something anyone can get such numbers.

totally unconvincing and deliberately inciting in messaging to curb open source. https://t.co/ZVKOZ5ksaW

— tokenbender (@tokenbender) February 24, 2026

Quoting:

Anthropic @AnthropicAI

We‚Äôve identified industrial-scale distillation attacks on our models by DeepSeek, Moonshot AI, and MiniMax.

These labs created over 24,000 fraudulent accounts and generated over 16 million exchanges with Claude, extracting its capabilities to train and improve their own models.

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
I wonder how soon we will get so much energy and sample efficiency in AI models that anyone with a laptop will be able to download a 100kb executable and have the model train on their CPU on their own files + maybe Wikipedia dump.

I suspect this will happen, just not sure when.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Of course, if development plateaus, all bets are off, but that isn't what is happening so far. It is very much Google, Anthropic and OpenAI, potentially joined by xAI & Meta, the open weights Chinese models (maybe Mistral) & a set of far trailing closed-model players (Amazon).

Of course, if development plateaus, all bets are off, but that isn't what is happening so far. It is very much Google, Anthropic and OpenAI, potentially joined by xAI & Meta, the open weights Chinese models (maybe Mistral) & a set of far trailing closed-model players (Amazon).

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 24, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Given gathering momentum, the set of real players in the frontier models space seems pretty stable, with the two big questions being whether xAI can continue to keep up and whether Meta can rejoin the frontier LLM race. We will likely know the answer to those in the coming months

item.description:

Paper: https://t.co/GEKTZULG3u

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 24, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

New randomized experiment shows AI narrows skill gaps. We found this among talent levels at the same job, but this paper looks at education. They find that AI reduces the gap between more & less educated people on a business task by 75% (but is it just the AI doing the work?) https://t.co/A1TMyWboOL

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
"You can just do stuff" is true, but what "stuff" you want to do, and whether it is good or bad that you are doing it, is increasingly important to understand.

"You can just do stuff" is true, but what "stuff" you want to do, and whether it is good or bad that you are doing it, is increasingly important to understand.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Collect your hard problems and good ideas now, they will get more valuable.

Increasingly, I see many people using AI to "do stuff" without any good ideas of what to do or pressing problems to solve. Agency without a sense of direction, or a bad direction, is not a good thing.

item.title: Zhihu Frontier (@ZhihuFrontier)
item.description:
üöÄ Today we want to share an article named "Six Months on Foundation Models = Ten Years in the World" from Zhihu contributor ËòëËèáÂÖàÁîü, which tells his pivot story ‚Äî and the results are real.

In 180 days:
‚Ä¢ üèÜ 1 Champion + ü•âü•â 2 Third Places at ICCV25 Multimodal Reasoning
‚Ä¢ Open-sourced EvoCUA ‚Üí Open-source SOTA on OSWorld
‚Ä¢ Jan 23, 2026: Hugging Face Daily Paper #1 (recognized by HF co-founder)
This is his first flagship work after switching from Ads/Recs to foundation models.

üß≠ Why pivot?
1Ô∏è‚É£ Industry shift
‚Ä¢ Search/Ads/Rec = distributing information.
‚Ä¢ Foundation models = generating info + executing tasks.
The evolution:
Chat ‚Üí CoT ‚Üí Agent (action & environment interaction) Not optimizing traffic allocation ‚Äî but replacing humans in task completion.
So he chose the growth frontier.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Personal calculus
‚Ä¢ In business teams: value = tied to business scale.
‚Ä¢ In foundation teams: tech itself is the product.
Representative work (SOTA, scaling laws) > KPI optimization, and portable capability > localized tricks.

üèó Where he positioned himself
He breaks the ecosystem into 4 layers:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Architecture (like Attention, MoE) - long period and more academic
2Ô∏è‚É£ Base model training (Pretrain/Post-train) - rely on resources heavily
3Ô∏è‚É£ Agent models (tool/computer use, RL-heavy)
4Ô∏è‚É£ AI-native apps
He chose 2 + 3, focusing on GUI Agents.
Why? It includes multimodal + RL + environment interaction + engineering depth.
Hard = high ceiling.

üî¨ How EvoCUA was built
Thousands of experiments + Millions of GPU hours.
üëâTheir core belief:
Let models evolve from their own failures.

üè† Three-step methodology
1Ô∏è‚É£ Benchmark deep dive
Before optimizing, fully understand OSWorld.
They:
‚Ä¢ Rebuilt evaluation pipelines (fixed major bugs)
‚Ä¢ Analyzed models like Qwen3-VL & OpenCUA
‚Ä¢ Built visualization + trajectory debugging tools
Found key blockers:
‚Ä¢ False "success" signals
‚Ä¢ Incomplete action space (e.g., no shift+click efficiency)
Without this, optimization is blind.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Stable baseline first
Pick base model ‚Üí verify consistent gains in-domain ‚Üí expand outward.
No reckless architecture tweaks & premature RL.
If baseline isn't stable, scaling collapses.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Scale with hypothesis
Start with RFT (Rejection Fine-Tuning).
Issue: Successful trajectories still contain noisy / redundant steps.
üí° Solution:
‚Ä¢ Step-level noise cleaning
‚Ä¢ Reflector-style improvements
‚Ä¢ Controlled ablations
‚Ä¢ Cold-start diversification
‚Ä¢ RL added only after scaling bottlenecks
Validated across multiple bases.

üß† Key lessons
‚Ä¢ High signal-to-noise data > raw volume
‚Ä¢ Cold-start diversity matters
‚Ä¢ Strict on-policy data for long-chain RL
‚Ä¢ Visualization is essential
‚Ä¢ Agent training is fragile
‚Ä¢ GUI randomness ‚Üí Pass@k measures robustness
Scaling isn't just about data.
Environment diversity must scale too.

üßò Advice for switchers
Foundation model work ‚â† fast A/B loops. You need:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Data intuition
2Ô∏è‚É£ Frontier sensitivity
3Ô∏è‚É£ Self-drive
4Ô∏è‚É£ A self-built evaluation system
Long cycles. High uncertainty.
Growth isn't measured by KPI dashboards.

EvoCUA is just step one. Next:
‚Ä¢ GUI Agent ‚Üí Omni-Agent
‚Ä¢ Deeper post-training
‚Ä¢ Online RL exploration
Build the road ‚Äî don't just optimize traffic on it.
üìñ Full article: https://t.co/VDfkCGUEbq
#EvoCUA #AgenticAI #FoundationModels #OpenSourceAI #RL #GUIAgent #AIEngineering

üöÄ Today we want to share an article named "Six Months on Foundation Models = Ten Years in the World" from Zhihu contributor ËòëËèáÂÖàÁîü, which tells his pivot story ‚Äî and the results are real.

In 180 days:
‚Ä¢ üèÜ 1 Champion + ü•âü•â 2 Third Places at ICCV25 Multimodal Reasoning
‚Ä¢ Open-sourced EvoCUA ‚Üí Open-source SOTA on OSWorld
‚Ä¢ Jan 23, 2026: Hugging Face Daily Paper #1 (recognized by HF co-founder)
This is his first flagship work after switching from Ads/Recs to foundation models.

üß≠ Why pivot?
1Ô∏è‚É£ Industry shift
‚Ä¢ Search/Ads/Rec = distributing information.
‚Ä¢ Foundation models = generating info + executing tasks.
The evolution:
Chat ‚Üí CoT ‚Üí Agent (action & environment interaction) Not optimizing traffic allocation ‚Äî but replacing humans in task completion.
So he chose the growth frontier.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Personal calculus
‚Ä¢ In business teams: value = tied to business scale.
‚Ä¢ In foundation teams: tech itself is the product.
Representative work (SOTA, scaling laws) > KPI optimization, and portable capability > localized tricks.

üèó Where he positioned himself
He breaks the ecosystem into 4 layers:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Architecture (like Attention, MoE) - long period and more academic
2Ô∏è‚É£ Base model training (Pretrain/Post-train) - rely on resources heavily
3Ô∏è‚É£ Agent models (tool/computer use, RL-heavy)
4Ô∏è‚É£ AI-native apps
He chose 2 + 3, focusing on GUI Agents.
Why? It includes multimodal + RL + environment interaction + engineering depth.
Hard = high ceiling.

üî¨ How EvoCUA was built
Thousands of experiments + Millions of GPU hours.
üëâTheir core belief:
Let models evolve from their own failures.

üè† Three-step methodology
1Ô∏è‚É£ Benchmark deep dive
Before optimizing, fully understand OSWorld.
They:
‚Ä¢ Rebuilt evaluation pipelines (fixed major bugs)
‚Ä¢ Analyzed models like Qwen3-VL & OpenCUA
‚Ä¢ Built visualization + trajectory debugging tools
Found key blockers:
‚Ä¢ False "success" signals
‚Ä¢ Incomplete action space (e.g., no shift+click efficiency)
Without this, optimization is blind.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Stable baseline first
Pick base model ‚Üí verify consistent gains in-domain ‚Üí expand outward.
No reckless architecture tweaks & premature RL.
If baseline isn't stable, scaling collapses.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Scale with hypothesis
Start with RFT (Rejection Fine-Tuning).
Issue: Successful trajectories still contain noisy / redundant steps.
üí° Solution:
‚Ä¢ Step-level noise cleaning
‚Ä¢ Reflector-style improvements
‚Ä¢ Controlled ablations
‚Ä¢ Cold-start diversification
‚Ä¢ RL added only after scaling bottlenecks
Validated across multiple bases.

üß† Key lessons
‚Ä¢ High signal-to-noise data > raw volume
‚Ä¢ Cold-start diversity matters
‚Ä¢ Strict on-policy data for long-chain RL
‚Ä¢ Visualization is essential
‚Ä¢ Agent training is fragile
‚Ä¢ GUI randomness ‚Üí Pass@k measures robustness
Scaling isn't just about data.
Environment diversity must scale too.

üßò Advice for switchers
Foundation model work ‚â† fast A/B loops. You need:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Data intuition
2Ô∏è‚É£ Frontier sensitivity
3Ô∏è‚É£ Self-drive
4Ô∏è‚É£ A self-built evaluation system
Long cycles. High uncertainty.
Growth isn't measured by KPI dashboards.

EvoCUA is just step one. Next:
‚Ä¢ GUI Agent ‚Üí Omni-Agent
‚Ä¢ Deeper post-training
‚Ä¢ Online RL exploration
Build the road ‚Äî don't just optimize traffic on it.

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
Big news today if you're into coding evals:

SWE-Bench Verified is dead!!

https://t.co/TKdjV4yc9U

i'm not sure if @HamelHusain is tired of me tagging him but it turns out @OpenAI really did look back at their own 2024 work and then you 1) look at the CoT and 2) look at the evals they realized that at LEAST 16.4% of SWE-Bench Verified should technically be unsolvable...

... and also that ALL frontier models, including OpenAI's own, are capable of solving them by sheer contamination (including being able to recite verbatim the entire SWE-Bench problem setup and solution, just by giving Task ID alone (!!!!)).

Heroic work from the OAI Evals team, and imo an important highlight on the fragility and messiness of Evals work in general. OpenAI spent the money to do 3 independent reviews of each problem in 2024 and AT LEAST SIXTEEN PERCENT OF THESE were still egregiously prolematic (as shown in screenshots). in this 2026 audit they then did 6 independent reviews from software engineers, with ADDITIONAL positive finding verification from a separate team, in order to arrive at today's conclusion.

If this happens to SWE-Bench Verified... what else is hiding in other benchmarks out there?

Big news today if you're into coding evals:

https://t.co/TKdjV4yc9U

i'm not sure if @HamelHusain is tired of me tagging him but it turns out @OpenAI really did look back at their own 2024 work and then you 1) look at the CoT and 2) look at the evals they realized that at LEAST 16.4% of SWE-Bench Verified should technically be unsolvable...

If this happens to SWE-Bench Verified... what else is hiding in other benchmarks out there?

— swyx (@swyx) February 23, 2026

Quoting:

Latent.Space @latentspacepod

üÜï The End of SWE-Bench Verified (2024-2026)

https://t.co/HCmogFFG8w

Today @OpenAIDevs is announcing the voluntary deprecation of SWE-Bench Verified! We're releasing a podcast + analysis in today's post.

Saturation of SWE-Bench has been a community hot topic for over a year - https://t.co/rUkUVFyvM1

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
Patient outcome stats don't include treatment options that are only available in the US.

Consider immunotherapy options. Many universal healthcare countries don't offer these (because too expensive) or introduce them several years or decades after the united states when the prices have dropped (because of US consumers).

Patient outcome stats don't include treatment options that are only available in the US.

Consider immunotherapy options. Many universal healthcare countries don't offer these (because too expensive) or introduce them several years or decades after the united states when the prices have dropped (because of US consumers).

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Wil @wilberightbak

@dvassallo @dagorenouf And where did you get that it's the best healthcare in the world? Do you have stats for patient outcomes?

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
"Red/green TDD" talks about how you can get much better results from most coding agents by encouraging them to use test-first development where they watch the tests fail before building an implementation that lets them pass https://t.co/2owEbkEFDI

"Red/green TDD" talks about how you can get much better results from most coding agents by encouraging them to use test-first development where they watch the tests fail before building an implementation that lets them pass https://t.co/2owEbkEFDI

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Simon Willison @simonw

"Writing code is cheap now" talks about the central challenge of agentic engineering: the cost to churn out working code has dropped to almost nothing, how does that impact our existing intuitions about how we work, both individually and as a team? https://t.co/7EgTINTsX0

item.title: Andrew Ng (@AndrewYNg)
item.description:
Will AI create new job opportunities? My daughter Nova loves cats, and her favorite color is yellow. For her 7th birthday, we got a cat-themed cake in yellow by first using Gemini‚Äôs Nano Banana to design it, and then asking a baker to create it using delicious sponge cake and icing. My daughter was delighted by this unique creation, and the process created additional work for the baker (which I feel privileged to have been able to afford).

Many people are worried about AI taking peoples‚Äô jobs. As a society we have a moral responsibility to take care of people whose livelihoods are harmed. At the same time, I see many opportunities for people to take on new jobs and grow their areas of responsibility.

We are still early on the path of AI generating a lot of new jobs. I don't know if baking AI-designed cakes will grow into a large business. (AI Fund is not pursuing this opportunity, because if we do, I will gain a lot of weight.) But throughout history, when people have invented tools that unleashed human creativity, large amounts of new and meaningful work have resulted. For instance, according to one study, over the past 150 years, falling employment in agriculture and manufacturing has been ‚Äúmore than offset by rapid growth in the caring, creative, technology, and business services sectors.‚Äù

AI is also growing the demand for many digital services, which can translate into more work for people creating, maintaining, selling, and expanding upon these services. For example, I used to carry out a limited number of web searches every day. Today, my agents carry out dramatically more web searches. For example, the Agentic Reviewer, which I started as a weekend project and Yixing Jiang then helped make much better, automatically reviews research articles. It uses a web search API to search for related work, and this generates a vastly larger number of web search queries a day than I have ever entered by hand.

The evolution of AI and software continues to accelerate, and the set of opportunities for things we can build still grows every day. I‚Äôve stopped writing code by hand. More controversially, I‚Äôve long stopped reading generated code. I realize I‚Äôm in the minority here, but I feel like I can get built most of what I want without having to look directly at coding syntax, and I operate at a higher level of abstraction using coding agents to manipulate code for me. Will conventional programming languages like Python and TypeScript go the way of assembly ‚Äî where it gets generated and used, but without direct examination by a human developer ‚Äî or will models compile directly from English prompts to byte code?

Either way, if every developer becomes 10x more productive, I don't think we‚Äôll end up with 1/10th as many developers, because the demand for custom software has no practical ceiling. Instead, the number of people who develop software will grow massively. In fact, I‚Äôm seeing early signs of ‚ÄúX Engineer‚Äù jobs, such as Recruiting Engineer or Marketing Engineer, which are people who sit in a certain business function X to create software for that function.

One thing I‚Äôm convinced of based on my experience with Nova‚Äôs birthday cake: AI will allow us to have a batter life!

[Original text: https://t.co/yws8drSTfO ]

For her 7th birthday, we got a cat-themed cake in yellow by first using Gemini‚Äôs Nano Banana to design it, and then asking a baker to create it using delicious sponge cake and icing. My daughter was delighted by this unique creation, and the process created additional work for the baker (which I feel privileged to have been able to afford).

Many people are worried about AI taking peoples‚Äô jobs. As a society we have a moral responsibility to take care of people whose livelihoods are harmed. At the same time, I see many opportunities for people to take on new jobs and grow their areas of responsibility.

We are still early on the path of AI generating a lot of new jobs. I don't know if baking AI-designed cakes will grow into a large business. (AI Fund is not pursuing this opportunity, because if we do, I will gain a lot of weight.) But throughout history, when people have invented tools that unleashed human creativity, large amounts of new and meaningful work have resulted. For instance, according to one study, over the past 150 years, falling employment in agriculture and manufacturing has been ‚Äúmore than offset by rapid growth in the caring, creative, technology, and business services sectors.‚Äù

AI is also growing the demand for many digital services, which can translate into more work for people creating, maintaining, selling, and expanding upon these services. For example, I used to carry out a limited number of web searches every day. Today, my agents carry out dramatically more web searches. For example, the Agentic Reviewer, which I started as a weekend project and Yixing Jiang then helped make much better, automatically reviews research articles. It uses a web search API to search for related work, and this generates a vastly larger number of web search queries a day than I have ever entered by hand.

The evolution of AI and software continues to accelerate, and the set of opportunities for things we can build still grows every day. I‚Äôve stopped writing code by hand. More controversially, I‚Äôve long stopped reading generated code. I realize I‚Äôm in the minority here, but I feel like I can get built most of what I want without having to look directly at coding syntax, and I operate at a higher level of abstraction using coding agents to manipulate code for me. Will conventional programming languages like Python and TypeScript go the way of assembly ‚Äî where it gets generated and used, but without direct examination by a human developer ‚Äî or will models compile directly from English prompts to byte code?

Either way, if every developer becomes 10x more productive, I don't think we‚Äôll end up with 1/10th as many developers, because the demand for custom software has no practical ceiling. Instead, the number of people who develop software will grow massively. In fact, I‚Äôm seeing early signs of ‚ÄúX Engineer‚Äù jobs, such as Recruiting Engineer or Marketing Engineer, which are people who sit in a certain business function X to create software for that function.

One thing I‚Äôm convinced of based on my experience with Nova‚Äôs birthday cake: AI will allow us to have a batter life!

[Original text: https://t.co/yws8drSTfO ]

— Andrew Ng (@AndrewYNg) February 23, 2026

(AI Fund is not pursuing this opportunity, because if we do, I will gain a lot of weight.) But throughout history, when people have invented tools that unleashed human creativity, large amounts of new and meaningful work have resulted. For instance, according to one study, over the past 150 years, falling employment in agriculture and manufacturing has been ‚Äúmore than offset by rapid growth in the caring, creative, technology, and business services sectors.‚Äù

AI is also growing the demand for many digital services, which can translate into more work for people creating, maintaining, selling, and expanding upon these services. For example, I used to carry out a limited number of web searches every day. Today, my agents carry out dramatically more web searches. For example, the Agentic Reviewer, which I started as a weekend project and Yixing Jiang then helped make much better, automatically reviews research articles. It uses a web search API to search for related work, and this generates a vastly larger number of web search queries a day than I have ever entered by hand.

The evolution of AI and software continues to accelerate, and the set of opportunities for things we can build still grows every day. I‚Äôve stopped writing code by hand. More controversially, I‚Äôve long stopped reading generated code. I realize I‚Äôm in the minority here, but I feel like I can get built most of what I want without having to look directly at coding syntax, and I operate at a higher level of abstraction using coding agents to manipulate code for me. Will conventional programming languages like Python and TypeScript go the way of assembly ‚Äî where it gets generated and used, but without direct examination by a human developer ‚Äî or will models compile directly from English prompts to byte code?

Either way, if every developer becomes 10x more productive, I don't think we‚Äôll end up with 1/10th as many developers, because the demand for custom software has no practical ceiling. Instead, the number of people who develop software will grow massively. In fact, I‚Äôm seeing early signs of ‚ÄúX Engineer‚Äù jobs, such as Recruiting Engineer or Marketing Engineer, which are people who sit in a certain business function X to create software for that function.

One thing I‚Äôm convinced of based on my experience with Nova‚Äôs birthday cake: AI will allow us to have a batter life!

[Original text: https://t.co/yws8drSTfO ]

Will AI create new job opportunities? My daughter Nova loves cats, and her favorite color is yellow. For her 7th birthday, we got a cat-themed cake in yellow by first using Gemini‚Äôs Nano Banana to design it, and then asking a baker to create it using delicious sponge cake and icing. My daughter was delighted by this unique creation, and the process created additional work for the baker (which I feel privileged to have been able to afford).

Many people are worried about AI taking peoples‚Äô jobs. As a society we have a moral responsibility to take care of people whose livelihoods are harmed. At the same time, I see many opportunities for people to take on new jobs and grow their areas of responsibility.

We are still early on the path of AI generating a lot of new jobs. I don't know if baking AI-designed cakes will grow into a large business. (AI Fund is not pursuing this opportunity, because if we do, I will gain a lot of weight.) But throughout history, when people have invented tools that unleashed human creativity, large amounts of new and meaningful work have resulted. For instance, according to one study, over the past 150 years, falling employment in agriculture and manufacturing has been ‚Äúmore than offset by rapid growth in the caring, creative, technology, and business services sectors.‚Äù

AI is also growing the demand for many digital services, which can translate into more work for people creating, maintaining, selling, and expanding upon these services. For example, I used to carry out a limited number of web searches every day. Today, my agents carry out dramatically more web searches. For example, the Agentic Reviewer, which I started as a weekend project and Yixing Jiang then helped make much better, automatically reviews research articles. It uses a web search API to search for related work, and this generates a vastly larger number of web search queries a day than I have ever entered by hand.

The evolution of AI and software continues to accelerate, and the set of opportunities for things we can build still grows every day. I‚Äôve stopped writing code by hand. More controversially, I‚Äôve long stopped reading generated code. I realize I‚Äôm in the minority here, but I feel like I can get built most of what I want without having to look directly at coding syntax, and I operate at a higher level of abstraction using coding agents to manipulate code for me. Will conventional programming languages like Python and TypeScript go the way of assembly ‚Äî where it gets generated and used, but without direct examination by a human developer ‚Äî or will models compile directly from English prompts to byte code?

Either way, if every developer becomes 10x more productive, I don't think we‚Äôll end up with 1/10th as many developers, because the demand for custom software has no practical ceiling. Instead, the number of people who develop software will grow massively. In fact, I‚Äôm seeing early signs of ‚ÄúX Engineer‚Äù jobs, such as Recruiting Engineer or Marketing Engineer, which are people who sit in a certain business function X to create software for that function.

One thing I‚Äôm convinced of based on my experience with Nova‚Äôs birthday cake: AI will allow us to have a batter life!

[Original text: https://t.co/yws8drSTfO ]

— Andrew Ng (@AndrewYNg) February 23, 2026

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@alexolegimas Looks like I was right about it being broadly influential. It is notable how much viral science fiction (grounded science fiction, but still) is able to influence markets and policy.

@alexolegimas Looks like I was right about it being broadly influential. It is notable how much viral science fiction (grounded science fiction, but still) is able to influence markets and policy.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

@alexolegimas But because people love stories, I suspect that the piece Citrini piece will be broadly influential

We really need a wider range of AI stories that include things like effective policy response and outcomes that have nuances that go beyond the future being either heaven or hell

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
Fun fact, TI83+ BASIC was my first programming language back in middle school! I even wrote this guide to programming in it: https://t.co/ORv26VZCYl

Many years later, I got a LinkedIn message from someone who read that guide in school, which set her on a journey to pursue a career in CS. It was such a meaningful thing to hear at the time!

Fun fact, TI83+ BASIC was my first programming language back in middle school! I even wrote this guide to programming in it: https://t.co/ORv26VZCYl

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
@arpit_bhayani @shobhitic update:

larger documents are less of a problem than they were in 2024 era. context windows are larger, and vectors are now better at "compression" than earlier as well

@arpit_bhayani @shobhitic update:

larger documents are less of a problem than they were in 2024 era. context windows are larger, and vectors are now better at "compression" than earlier as well

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Arpit Bhayani @arpit_bhayani

@shobhitic vector similarity solves similar problem, but as document size increases vector similarities start to have more false positives.

Hence, doing vector sim with large documents typically involves splitting docs into segments and then applying some sort of agg.
item.content:encoded:

Arpit Bhayani @arpit_bhayani

@shobhitic vector similarity solves similar problem, but as document size increases vector similarities start to have more false positives.

Hence, doing vector sim with large documents typically involves splitting docs into segments and then applying some sort of agg.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@alexolegimas But because people love stories, I suspect that the piece Citrini piece will be broadly influential

We really need a wider range of AI stories that include things like effective policy response and outcomes that have nuances that go beyond the future being either heaven or hell

@alexolegimas But because people love stories, I suspect that the piece Citrini piece will be broadly influential

We really need a wider range of AI stories that include things like effective policy response and outcomes that have nuances that go beyond the future being either heaven or hell

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Like AGI 2027, this is "hard" science fiction - it is an attempt at scenario building (which is useful!) but not a fully plausible path.

I think @alexolegimas's write-ups on the potential economics around AGI are a more useful basis for your predictions: https://t.co/0DxS25fXpe https://t.co/WKoF4PZvj6 https://t.co/CS7KSxT43r

item.description:
It could also be from a single press release or a paper from 2024 that somehow goes viral here. Or else a near-future science fiction story, those sometimes trigger panic too.

It could also be from a single press release or a paper from 2024 that somehow goes viral here. Or else a near-future science fiction story, those sometimes trigger panic too.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 23, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Looking at my feed & the universal "AI is taking over the world by 2027" posts, seems we are due for a wave of "AI hitting a wall" soon, given the whipsawing between extremes. I wonder if this time it will be caused by a single academic paper, an analyst report or just a rumor.

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Looking at my feed & the universal "AI is taking over the world by 2027" posts, seems we are due for a wave of "AI hitting a wall" soon, given the whipsawing between extremes. I wonder if this time it will be caused by a single academic paper, an analyst report or just a rumor.

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@Eduardopto True, but the cost of a bad bet has gone down. Spending six months writing code for the wrong product will kill a startup. Spending a few days is much more survivable, and you get to roll the dice a lot more times

@Eduardopto True, but the cost of a bad bet has gone down. Spending six months writing code for the wrong product will kill a startup. Spending a few days is much more survivable, and you get to roll the dice a lot more times

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Ed @Eduardopto

@simonw vibe coding gets you to launch, not to product market fit. the hard part was never writing the code, it was figuring out what to build and for who

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
At the task level, change may be fast (coding, marketing), but building the systems to coordinate work around jaggedness and integrate across tasks is going to take time.

That doesn‚Äôt mean that we won‚Äôt see waves of disruption across industries, but unlikely to be all at once.

At the task level, change may be fast (coding, marketing), but building the systems to coordinate work around jaggedness and integrate across tasks is going to take time.

That doesn‚Äôt mean that we won‚Äôt see waves of disruption across industries, but unlikely to be all at once.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

People on this site systematically overestimate the speed at which companies can deeply adopt AI & underestimate the impact of AI‚Äôs jagged abilities in limiting AI‚Äôs utility in the short run.

Work will certainly start to change but companies have a lot of inertia & change slower

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
The ability of AI to understand video/images seems to be largely underexplored and underexploited. There are a lot of economically valuable applications to having an AI watch the world in real time, even with errors & limitations, and I have seen few products or papers on it.

The ability of AI to understand video/images seems to be largely underexplored and underexploited. There are a lot of economically valuable applications to having an AI watch the world in real time, even with errors & limitations, and I have seen few products or papers on it.

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
I learned geometry twice.

I was forced to learn it at school. It made no sense and I hated it. I forgot everything after I passed the exam.

I learned it again when I got obsessed with game programming. Everything made sense and I loved it.

The school part was 100% unnecessary. https://t.co/otAZet6Shz

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
Walter was pre Obamacare. Now every insurance must cap out of pocket payments to $9,200 for an individual and $18,400 for a family.

And even if Walter chose a treatment that insurance didn‚Äôt cover (these are treatments usually not available in universal healthcare countries), then Walter could have financed the payment over 15 years for a reasonable $1600/mo.

Walter was pre Obamacare. Now every insurance must cap out of pocket payments to $9,200 for an individual and $18,400 for a family.

And even if Walter chose a treatment that insurance didn‚Äôt cover (these are treatments usually not available in universal healthcare countries), then Walter could have financed the payment over 15 years for a reasonable $1600/mo.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@nahuelzn My apologies for being unclear on tone. I meant it as a discussion of the wider impacts of AI on society. If the AI labs are right about the technology, they are still likely wrong about the implications & we should worry about that. It can be hard to get tone right in a post

@nahuelzn My apologies for being unclear on tone. I meant it as a discussion of the wider impacts of AI on society. If the AI labs are right about the technology, they are still likely wrong about the implications & we should worry about that. It can be hard to get tone right in a post

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Nahuel Lanz√≥n @nahuelzn

@emollick I re-read the post to see if I misread it and still think it sounds like "look, AI ceos finally were right and we ignored them, now we're in a hurry". Even when your own opinion was that framing the discussion about jobs in that way were harmful and provided AI skeptics an angle

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
The failure to articulate non-ominous visions of the future (even Machines of Loving Grace fails to explain what life would actually be like) is going to be a problem.

The failure to articulate non-ominous visions of the future (even Machines of Loving Grace fails to explain what life would actually be like) is going to be a problem.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

The CEOs of the AI labs have spent the last two years ominously discussing massive future job losses, and were mostly ignored. As AI becomes more salient, workers and policymakers are going to start taking that kind of talk seriously, with big implications for the industry.

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
The outcome numbers look at population averages so they get skewed by people who neglect their health, don‚Äôt seek treatment, seek it too late, antivaxers, bad neighborhoods, and other things. If you‚Äòre not that person, population averages don‚Äôt matter to you individually.

If Bezos were to need some healthcare, do you think he‚Äôll go abroad? He can. But probably he won‚Äôt.

The outcome numbers look at population averages so they get skewed by people who neglect their health, don‚Äôt seek treatment, seek it too late, antivaxers, bad neighborhoods, and other things. If you‚Äòre not that person, population averages don‚Äôt matter to you individually.

If Bezos were to need some healthcare, do you think he‚Äôll go abroad? He can. But probably he won‚Äôt.

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

inthezone @inthezoneuk

@dvassallo @dagorenouf It‚Äôs the most expensive system in the world. Even with insurance, many have to pay thousands in excess, all assuming your condition is covered. Hundreds of thousands go bankrupt each year due to medical bills.

My cousin who works as a nurse in the American system, stated that

@dagorenouf US healthcare is best in the world. You just have to pay for it. If you‚Äôre poor, it‚Äôs free. If you‚Äôre old, it‚Äôs free as well. If you‚Äôre almost poor, it‚Äôs subsidized. But you can afford it.

Education doesn‚Äôt matter anymore. Anyone can learn anything from anywhere in the world.

Lots of AI-washing going on.

AI-native isn‚Äôt about using LLMs.
It‚Äôs about cost structure inversion.

In product companies, tokens start to rival S&M.

In services companies, tokens start to rival payroll.

When compute scales faster than people, you‚Äôre operating differently.

Vaibhav Tulsyan @xennygrimmato_

Now that Taalas has blown up, I think people should read the PIM-GPT paper.
PIM-GPT leverages DRAM-based PIM designs for executing multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations directly in the DRAM chips, eliminating the need to move matrix data off-chip. Non-linear functions and data https://t.co/fNVvTPDlez https://t.co/GUIniRFoaB

Replying to:

swyx @swyx

yesterday we chatted with @martin_casado and @sarahdingwang on the pod and he happened to do basic math‚Ñ¢ on the logic of asics

today @taalas_inc launched their HC1 asic that can inference 17k tok/s. Sure, it's a shitty 3.1 8B today which is a 1.5 year gap.

But read the details https://t.co/xmMfsHoGMl https://t.co/4wCffRdQsm

item.title: tokenbender (@tokenbender)
item.description:
the trajectory is set - the models would learn to write a minimal scaffold given any task. humans would teach how to whitelist/blacklist based on policies. everything to descend the reliability optim hill.

until the self-policing also gets absorbed in the "system" itself.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@Afinetheorem I like this counterexample, puts some emphasis on the need for the rising tide of AI to lift all boats.

@Afinetheorem I like this counterexample, puts some emphasis on the need for the rising tide of AI to lift all boats.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Kevin A. Bryan @Afinetheorem

When we go from 50% ag workers to 1% over two generations, we don't see any change in overall employment, wages go up, and the people who get rich are not the people who owned farmland or John Deere in 1920. This is a possible AI future! 2/2

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@algekalipso But. isn't qualia too tightly constrained by evolutionary history?

we see distinctions in qualia space because they've helped us in our evolutionary past.

Having said that, the redness of red will remain a big mystery to me.

@algekalipso But. isn't qualia too tightly constrained by evolutionary history?

we see distinctions in qualia space because they've helped us in our evolutionary past.

Having said that, the redness of red will remain a big mystery to me.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Captain Pleasure, Andr√©s G√≥mez Emilsson @algekalipso

Someone asked: "Why does color even exist as an experience? Motion, texture, object detection... all of that could work with black/white information. There's no obvious reason perceived RGB should exist as it does. There's an explanatory gap."

Indeed! I struggle to even conceive

marsa.h @Marsagenesis

@paraschopra But why restrict consciousness to animals with brains when know even single cell organism has a goal directed behavior, memory, and information processing?
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
If you have a large pool of people, their "jaggedness" cancels out because they have diverse skills and talents. 1000 agents of the same model are not the same thing, they have the same weakspots and, potentially, are more vulnerable to groupthink-like problems than humans.

If you have a large pool of people, their "jaggedness" cancels out because they have diverse skills and talents. 1000 agents of the same model are not the same thing, they have the same weakspots and, potentially, are more vulnerable to groupthink-like problems than humans.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Jaggedness remains a key feature of LLMs & I have yet to see a clearly articulated argument about why it will disappear. A jagged general intelligence (not quite an oxymoron, as humans are too) still creates lots of bottlenecks that require people & slow many kinds of take-off.

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
Thank you for working on this, I've been testing it and here's a bunch of feedback:
- Hard to configure, even for the bots, they dont know about it

- Cannot set custom voice models: The modelByChannel is sorely needed to allow faster models on voice channels (can't wait to try out spark) but is rejected by schema validator? Looks like it didn't end up in the schema validator

- Support for other TTS models is impossible, via plugins of otherwise. I tried to setup with @inworld_ai TTS and bubkis, it's not supported. would love to open up support for other TTS models

- Cannot set custom instructions for voice, there's no metadata injected for the LLM to know it's now "talking" vs "texting". there needs to be, because LLMs spit out a SHIT ton of text, and for voice it's boring to listen to

- Streaming! Very very important to have streming and chunking enabled for true speed.

I'm sure @kwindla has a bunch of other ideas of how to improve this, but I'd love to see the bot conversation abilities improve, this is a great start!

Thank you for working on this, I've been testing it and here's a bunch of feedback:
- Hard to configure, even for the bots, they dont know about it

- Cannot set custom voice models: The modelByChannel is sorely needed to allow faster models on voice channels (can't wait to try out spark) but is rejected by schema validator? Looks like it didn't end up in the schema validator

- Support for other TTS models is impossible, via plugins of otherwise. I tried to setup with @inworld_ai TTS and bubkis, it's not supported. would love to open up support for other TTS models

- Cannot set custom instructions for voice, there's no metadata injected for the LLM to know it's now "talking" vs "texting". there needs to be, because LLMs spit out a SHIT ton of text, and for voice it's boring to listen to

- Streaming! Very very important to have streming and chunking enabled for true speed.

I'm sure @kwindla has a bunch of other ideas of how to improve this, but I'd love to see the bot conversation abilities improve, this is a great start!

— Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Shadow @4shad0wed

Ok so I spent like 13 hours yesterday and I have some really fun stuff for Discord from both myself and several contributors. Long list incoming:

‚≠ê You can now VC with your agents in servers! Use either the /vc command, or set specific channels in your config that your agent https://t.co/CB4jf4iXbF

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
This account keeps posting older papers as new releases with AI generated commentary, but this paper is from June 2025, where it sparked some interesting debate but basically turned out to not be that relevant in the last year as models improved. https://t.co/es7yFdrhE0 https://t.co/byrDb8rEeo

This account keeps posting older papers as new releases with AI generated commentary, but this paper is from June 2025, where it sparked some interesting debate but basically turned out to not be that relevant in the last year as models improved. https://t.co/es7yFdrhE0 https://t.co/byrDb8rEeo

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 21, 2026

Quoting:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Every call I have had this week has had someone ask a question about the Apple paper.

I think its worth reflecting on why any time a "AI must fail" paper comes out (also: model collapse), it gets a lot of buzz & why the many "AI does this well" papers don't. Discomfort with AI?

item.title: Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward)
item.description:
@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Giving vendors a free pass just because their oversights can be fixed by every single user adding additional safeguards is not how secure systems are built.

@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Giving vendors a free pass just because their oversights can be fixed by every single user adding additional safeguards is not how secure systems are built.

— Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Jeremy Howard @jeremyphoward

@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Respectfully, I think you misunderstood it. The article clearly shows how the issue can be fixed both client-side and LLM-side, and suggests both.

Structured LLM tool call requests can be easily correctly and fully validated on both ends, but OpenAI does it server-side.

item.title: tokenbender (@tokenbender)
item.description:
@alxfazio super, was working on something to minimise error variance and used the same approach.

i think this style is going to by everywhere soon, it seems the right solution for the models at this stage and current ‚Äúkeep on praying in md that it works‚Äù approach.

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:
The new hill I will die on:

Every night right before you go to sleep you should throw one wild project idea at Codex/Claude. Something that almost certainly won‚Äôt work, but it doesn‚Äôt matter because you were asleep anyway. I call it my YOLO prompt.

Note the "tokens" badge at the top of the ReadMe. The whole repo is ~36k tokens - you can load it all into claude and still have >100k tokens to work with before you start running into context rot.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
A good Claw can already do most lightweight phone ‚Äúdoing‚Äù work, and those agents are unoptimized messes right now.

Makes me wonder what Apple is giving up by bowing out of the LLM building world. I suspect a lot more than they thought.

A good Claw can already do most lightweight phone ‚Äúdoing‚Äù work, and those agents are unoptimized messes right now.

Makes me wonder what Apple is giving up by bowing out of the LLM building world. I suspect a lot more than they thought.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

I don‚Äôt see as much discussion over the nature of phone OSs in the era of AI but it feels like it will change. I basically want to use my phone for two things (a) connect to legacy apps & (b) do stuff.

Pretty convinced that for all (b) tasks I would rather talk to a good agent

item.title: tokenbender (@tokenbender)
item.description:
@glimpse_gl i just feel the "my skill is too abstract for training data" market has been receding continuously for a while.

i am inclined to give the current direction (for clearly definable usecases) a benefit of that.

@glimpse_gl i just feel the "my skill is too abstract for training data" market has been receding continuously for a while.

i am inclined to give the current direction (for clearly definable usecases) a benefit of that.

— tokenbender (@tokenbender) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Glimpse @glimpse_gl

@tokenbender sure you can write software and digest information faster, but there are meta skills like critical thinking for which the gap still exists. acquisition of such meta skills has barely accelerated with ai

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
I generally use subagents with worktrees to do parallelizable work that doesn‚Äôt conflict, eg. large codebase migrations where each agent gets a few folders. It‚Äôs been a big speed up for that.

Probably a little more we can do to make the ux smooth for non-independent work, though currently I think it will just work and the main agent would resolve conflicts fine. Enabling agent teams may help also, so the agents can better coordinate their work when it overlaps

I generally use subagents with worktrees to do parallelizable work that doesn‚Äôt conflict, eg. large codebase migrations where each agent gets a few folders. It‚Äôs been a big speed up for that.

Probably a little more we can do to make the ux smooth for non-independent work, though currently I think it will just work and the main agent would resolve conflicts fine. Enabling agent teams may help also, so the agents can better coordinate their work when it overlaps

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Addy Osmani @addyosmani

@bcherny Happy to see this ship! Parallel agents are great but merge conflict resolution has been a manual process. Do you do anything to auto resolve these once the agents are done working?
item.content:encoded:

Probably a little more we can do to make the ux smooth for non-independent work, though currently I think it will just work and the main agent would resolve conflicts fine. Enabling agent teams may help also, so the agents can better coordinate their work when it overlaps

item.title: tokenbender (@tokenbender)
item.description:
@staghado yes i used the q8 version, it is quite good, close to full agentic ocr in few cases.

but still gets difficult with pages with multiple figures or big tables.

@staghado yes i used the q8 version, it is quite good, close to full agentic ocr in few cases.

but still gets difficult with pages with multiple figures or big tables.

— tokenbender (@tokenbender) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

staghado @staghado

@tokenbender i have made some choices to improve speed that might affect a general pdf to markdown performance: 1/ limited the image resolution to half what it‚Äôs trained for and 2/ quantized the model to 4-bit for faster generation.
both these affect results significantly sadly!

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
A simple reminder.

For India‚Äôs currency to remain valuable, India must have something valuable to export to the world. Historically its has been cheap labour and growth story but when western countries replace that with AI and discover high growth industries in their home ground, rupee value could drop significantly and evening India imports would become dramatically costly.

And we do import a lot! Oil, electronics, gold. All of it would become expensive.

This is why India must remain competitive on the global stage. Our population will quickly go from being a growth driver to being a liability if we don‚Äôt ramp up on innovation and R&D.

It‚Äôs honestly an existential matter for the country‚Äôs future.

This is why India must remain competitive on the global stage. Our population will quickly go from being a growth driver to being a liability if we don‚Äôt ramp up on innovation and R&D.

It‚Äôs honestly an existential matter for the country‚Äôs future.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 21, 2026

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
Personally, I‚Äôve been finding subagent worktrees useful for 1-shotting large batch changes like codebase-wide code migrations. Previously, these would have been a single plan (less well executed), a Ralph loop (doesn‚Äôt always work), a custom harness with agent SDK in a python loop (more code), or a team.

I don‚Äôt use ‚Äîworktree as much but the team is split roughly 50/50 with half using worktrees and half preferring multiple git checkouts or multiple tabs in the Desktop app.

Personally, I‚Äôve been finding subagent worktrees useful for 1-shotting large batch changes like codebase-wide code migrations. Previously, these would have been a single plan (less well executed), a Ralph loop (doesn‚Äôt always work), a custom harness with agent SDK in a python loop (more code), or a team.

I don‚Äôt use ‚Äîworktree as much but the team is split roughly 50/50 with half using worktrees and half preferring multiple git checkouts or multiple tabs in the Desktop app.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Numman Ali @nummanali

I have a few problems with worktrees:
- you need to reinstall everything
- you need to clean up after
- conflicts arise again on merge
- different agents handle it their way

I suppose for incremental changes that are tight this makes sense

But isn‚Äôt that going backwards? https://t.co/vQTkurMwLz

tokenbender @tokenbender

as we unlock longer contexts and engineer good reuse of previous sessions, we would start hill climbing new benches like arc agi 4 or whatever hours after release, what after that?
item.content:encoded:
so the skill gap means nothing. the only thing that matters is how well you can 1) acquire resources to compete, 2) access channels or humans that allow truth discovery better than others and 3) make everything cheaper and faster in your ecosystem using this unlock.

so the skill gap means nothing. the only thing that matters is how well you can 1) acquire resources to compete, 2) access channels or humans that allow truth discovery better than others and 3) make everything cheaper and faster in your ecosystem using this unlock.

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@robinhanson by inference, therefore, we should bias towards concluding that phenomenal consciousness must have an adaptive role

epiphenomena is a dead-end when it comes to empirical investigation, so you might as well assume causalty

@robinhanson by inference, therefore, we should bias towards concluding that phenomenal consciousness must have an adaptive role

epiphenomena is a dead-end when it comes to empirical investigation, so you might as well assume causalty

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Robin Hanson @robinhanson

@paraschopra If, by the usual assumption, we could have all the same physical systems and processes with or without phenomenal consciousness, how could it possibly help animals to be adaptive to have it, vs not have it?

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
yesterday we chatted with @martin_casado and @sarahdingwang on the pod and he happened to do basic math‚Ñ¢ on the logic of asics

today @taalas_inc launched their HC1 asic that can inference 17k tok/s. Sure, it's a shitty 3.1 8B today which is a 1.5 year gap.

But read the details to the HC2 this winter, and do the math ‚Äî this timeline will converge to 0 in the next 2 years.

Build accordingly.

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Uday Yatnalli @udaysy

@bcherny the subagent isolation is the part i care about most. running parallel agents on the same repo without merge conflicts was painful before this. does the CLI version auto-cleanup worktrees when agents finish?
item.content:encoded:
@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
1/ Use claude --worktree for isolation

To run Claude Code in its own git worktree, just start it with the --worktree option. You can also name your worktree, or have Claude name it for you.

Use this to run multiple parallel Claude Code sessions in the same git repo, without the code edits clobbering each other.

You can also pass the --tmux flag to launch Claude in its own Tmux session.

1/ Use claude --worktree for isolation

To run Claude Code in its own git worktree, just start it with the --worktree option. You can also name your worktree, or have Claude name it for you.

Use this to run multiple parallel Claude Code sessions in the same git repo, without the code edits clobbering each other.

You can also pass the --tmux flag to launch Claude in its own Tmux session.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Boris Cherny @bcherny

Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now https://t.co/cjOXhUDL0i

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
## the egocentric fallacy: "the most important part of a trend will happen to be right now when i randomly decide to care a lot about it because of some dude's post"

just to punch strawmen with Han (whom i love), this meta-principle of "choose the laggards in hopes they catch up" is a noob mistake and has a lower chance of working than most people are trained to appreciate (because they fundamentally want to believe in equality when capitalism fundamentally does not).

generation after generation of investors from Thiel to @Chamath have learned painful lessons to double down on winners rather than do relative value trades.

a simple thought exercise is to ask if the Software Engineering number goes up to 80% or 90% in the next 5 years would you be better of working on Back Office Automation? (no, the answer is no, some folks are so capitalism illiterate you need that to be spelled out) . So then if we just zoomed from 10 to 50% in the last 2 years, it is actually a classic egotistical fallacy that this exact moment is when AI x SWE peaked and it's all relative downside from here vs other domains, which is what is implied by the chart below: who are you, who are we, what evidence do you have, to say we are anywhere even close to done on the largest product market fit we've seen in software business history?

@nlw has been echoing my thoughts here - kode is the lions share of agi and basically by betting on anything else you may well be rich and you may well be happier and you may well have much more positive social impact on the world.... but do not confuse that for having higher expected value.

— swyx (@swyx) February 21, 2026

Quoting:

Han Wang @handotdev

what I would be working on if I started another company today https://t.co/kKDFxcbtZv https://t.co/7dpDyiHAW6

@nlw has been echoing my thoughts here - kode is the lions share of agi and basically by betting on anything else you may well be rich and you may well be happier and you may well have much more positive social impact on the world.... but do not confuse that for having higher expected value.

## the egocentric fallacy: "the most important part of a trend will happen to be right now when i randomly decide to care a lot about it because of some dude's post"

just to punch strawmen with Han (whom i love), this meta-principle of "choose the laggards in hopes they catch up" is a noob mistake and has a lower chance of working than most people are trained to appreciate (because they fundamentally want to believe in equality when capitalism fundamentally does not).

generation after generation of investors from Thiel to @Chamath have learned painful lessons to double down on winners rather than do relative value trades.

a simple thought exercise is to ask if the Software Engineering number goes up to 80% or 90% in the next 5 years would you be better of working on Back Office Automation? (no, the answer is no, some folks are so capitalism illiterate you need that to be spelled out) . So then if we just zoomed from 10 to 50% in the last 2 years, it is actually a classic egotistical fallacy that this exact moment is when AI x SWE peaked and it's all relative downside from here vs other domains, which is what is implied by the chart below: who are you, who are we, what evidence do you have, to say we are anywhere even close to done on the largest product market fit we've seen in software business history?

@nlw has been echoing my thoughts here - kode is the lions share of agi and basically by betting on anything else you may well be rich and you may well be happier and you may well have much more positive social impact on the world.... but do not confuse that for having higher expected value.

— swyx (@swyx) February 21, 2026

Quoting:

Han Wang @handotdev

what I would be working on if I started another company today https://t.co/kKDFxcbtZv https://t.co/7dpDyiHAW6

Tomasz Darmetko üáµüá±üá™üá∫üá∫üá¶ @Isinlor

@jeremyphoward @OpenAI Why are the agents not sandboxed? We have wonderful tools to do it - VMs, containers of various types - we can have very tight control on what any code can do inside a sandbox. If you don't have a proper sandbox, then there are no restrictions. The models are wicked smart.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
At this point, in any call, it is likely someone is AI transcribing, whether they tell you (& whether that is legal or not).

We really need clear norms & rules about how these transcripts can be used, since AI makes them searchable/applicable in lots of ways no one ever expected

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:
One annoying thing about agentic programming is that it doesn't understand when I am giving a hand-wavy answer.

Me: "The PDF you made was one page, it should be way longer, like 50 pages or something"

Codex: "Got it, I will make a PDF of exactly 50 pages"

item.description:
Georgi's llama.cpp really kicked off the whole local model thing in my opinion - it made original Llama usable on personal computers, I wrote about it back in March 2023 https://t.co/WZ3nzpZRNT https://t.co/rJe9iXG3Mm https://t.co/s5c5mLUjQF

Georgi's llama.cpp really kicked off the whole local model thing in my opinion - it made original Llama usable on personal computers, I wrote about it back in March 2023 https://t.co/WZ3nzpZRNT https://t.co/rJe9iXG3Mm https://t.co/s5c5mLUjQF

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 20, 2026

Quoting:

Georgi Gerganov @ggerganov

Today https://t.co/jFknDoasSy joins Hugging Face

Together we will continue to build ggml, make llama.cpp more accessible and empower the open-source community. Our joint mission is to make local AI easy and efficient to use by everyone on their own hardware. https://t.co/IvRiSZ95Hr

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
You should always intersperse reading when thinking.

If you keep on reading, you‚Äôll never get a chance to integrate and come up with your own thoughts.

If you keep on thinking, you‚Äôll miss out on ‚Äúfree‚Äù cognitive labor done by others, get biased and keep reinventing the wheel.

You should always intersperse reading when thinking.

If you keep on reading, you‚Äôll never get a chance to integrate and come up with your own thoughts.

If you keep on thinking, you‚Äôll miss out on ‚Äúfree‚Äù cognitive labor done by others, get biased and keep reinventing the wheel.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 20, 2026

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
Steal this idea.

Disposable email, phone number and credit cards for AI agents so they can act on your behalf without messing up your real life.

I feel this would be inevitable as we give our agents more autonomy on the web.

item.title: tokenbender (@tokenbender)
item.description:
@max_paperclips fascinating, if you also go ahead and add a leaderboard for them to look at then that might collapse the choices though. as sensible choice is to always consult the best option given task description and no other constraints.

@max_paperclips fascinating, if you also go ahead and add a leaderboard for them to look at then that might collapse the choices though. as sensible choice is to always consult the best option given task description and no other constraints.

— tokenbender (@tokenbender) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

Shannon Sands @max_paperclips

Multiagent orchestrator social dynamics for agents on code tasks are pretty fascinating

Opus will happily delegate to new agents - but doesn't seem to like predefined agents. It prefers prompting them directly with custom system prompts & instructions, for what seem to be

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
Hot take: anyone who says AI cannot do X will be proven wrong in the arc of history.

The simple case for this is that if a blind profess (evolution) stumbled upon our kind of intelligence, why wouldn‚Äôt a process with foresight (human intelligence) that‚Äôs also strongly motivated (economically) be able to do the same?

AGI is really a matter of when, not a matter of if.

Hot take: anyone who says AI cannot do X will be proven wrong in the arc of history.

The simple case for this is that if a blind profess (evolution) stumbled upon our kind of intelligence, why wouldn‚Äôt a process with foresight (human intelligence) that‚Äôs also strongly motivated (economically) be able to do the same?

AGI is really a matter of when, not a matter of if.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 20, 2026
